page.lettertext:
fol.286r
S
r
Tho Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
I doe not write w
t
any hope,
at this my
letter will finde yo
r
L. in
Flushing.
But yet this post c
o
ming to me, and having
newly now receaved by my
L. Burghes
servaunt, a letter from yo
r
L. of
e last of
Oc
t
. I could not but signifie of
e shocke
deliverie, and also thanke yo
w
most
hartely for
e m ater of yo
r
letter. It hath
eased me greatly of a great deal of me-
lancholie. For I doubt not a whitte, but
that yow may have good meanes, to knowe
w
at
is intended as touching my returne: and
w
at
yo
w
knowe, I make account, yo
w
will
signifie unto me, assone as yow may. W
ch
in
truth I shall esteeme as a singular benefit
among a great many former, for w
ch
I hold
my self deepely indebted to yo
r
L. I am
sorie for
at yo
w
write of
e weakenes of yo
r
body,
at it should so c
o
tinue. But yet I trust
e aire of
England,
and
e light of yo
r
frindes, will restoare yo
w
very quickly.
I pray yo
w
hartely if yo
w
heare, w
at
is
said to be
e
errand of
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
unto
the states, lett me have a letter from yo
w
,
though I think yo
w
will be gone, before
this come unto yo
w
.
And so I bidde yo
w
for this p
nt
most hartely farewell.
Fr
o
e Hage N
o
16
Yo
r
L. assured and at c
o
maundem
t
Tho. Bodley
